messages: 53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:06): http://www.securityfocus.com/bid/18992
6be6b0b15ab34076b013425f521668ee (23:07): Interesting: local: no, remote: no...
8ba6f29932eeb582d2d6e4e257d5f6fd (23:09): lol then?
8ba6f29932eeb582d2d6e4e257d5f6fd (23:09): discovered by h00lyshit heh
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:10): no, its definitely local.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:10): any 2.6 system (other than 2.16.17.5) is rootable.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:10): http://downloads.securityfocus.com/vulnerabilities/exploits/h00lyshit.c
8ba6f29932eeb582d2d6e4e257d5f6fd (23:13): luckily my production internet servers are running 2.4.x
e66f7175232268e7e1cd00fdf001f8a5 (23:14): luckily ,mine are running sol 10 ;)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:14): I suspect "vendors" are going to have a difficult time rolling out a fix
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (23:15): del: why?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:15): as this will only go into 2.6.17.5 and won't be backported to a "stable" 2.6 kernel unless someone like Red Hat does it.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:15): RHEL is still using 2.6.9
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (23:15): i wouldn't imagine it's too hard to backport given the 2.6.17 patch
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (23:16): red hat will do it, this is the reason they have alan cox and other kernel coders on the payroll
53e86cb71746c2a78d3aaf322da11ffc (23:16): still likely to take a while
6be6b0b15ab34076b013425f521668ee (23:17): delewis: but isn't 2.6.17.6 the stable? So it's fixed in it?
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (23:17): saltsa: many linux distributions don't use the current stable kernel
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (23:17): they use old versions with patches to fix things like this
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:17): Saltsa: why do you think RHEL is still using 2.6.9?
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (23:17): distributions tend to use whatever version they shipped :)
4fe573ff41aefb42de56ddf2771295ea (23:18): i imagine fedora will have a fix quite quickly, they tend to upgrade to the latest kernel the moment it's released ;-)
c55963a3bec158d36e87abc2f9085a9e (23:18): although for some reason debian thinks it's ok to randomly upgrade gmake from one incompatible version to another
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:18): well, this would prove to be entertaining
8ba6f29932eeb582d2d6e4e257d5f6fd (23:19): are there any other places i can get original SUNW* packages other than my CDs
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:19): detach-: of course not.

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:19): like the media.

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:20): detach-: so, copy all the packages to an NFS export

53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (23:20): which is what you would have if you were doing Solaris installs the proper way -- Jumpstart.

526994d5acccce31af4afbec5d754214 (00:21): Hello, I succeeded in Live Update (for the first time) from 42a to 43. One thing I don't understand, after LU, GRUB uses the menu.lst file under the original boot slice, and there's no menu.lst under the /boot/grub of new boot slice, why?
abe59155aa41ae19e4ea964e9dd4b200 (00:24): http://www.bagdadsoftware.de")
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:26): i have a disk that is zeroed out, i know the type of it. what option/action within format should be used to give the disk a label?
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:27): yarinh just use the default
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:27): type label
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:27): save
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:27): exit
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:29): uh ... i typed format and am now formatting it ... d'uh
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:34): rodrickbrown: what does that format-thing do exactly? check for defective sectors or something?
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:40): _tsoome_: which isn't exactly what i wanted ... damnit ...
9ecc6d980497546dc59d5a75894560b3 (00:41): thats how you learn the value of manuals....
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:42): yarihm, echo "label" >/tmp/label
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:42): format -f /tmp/label /dev/dsk/c0t0d0s2
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:42): i believe is what you want
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:43): that will take some time to complete i guess :) i hope it does not damage the drive
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:43): rodrickbrown: thank you
6b88ad0c0d868f527e66c1b8fcde89a3 (00:43): _tsoome_: yeah. the short description sounded reasonable. well, that's life
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:44): actually you just need the shortname
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:45): for disks in $(echo |format|awk '/c[0-9]/{ print $2}') ; do format -f /tmp/label $disks
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:45): if you want to label all disks
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:46): ; done
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:49): that's only if he needs to copy the vtoc i dont think tht's what he wants
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (00:50): hes just trying to label his disk
